choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

 

Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

 

The autosomal dominant condition known as Huntington disease (HD) is characterized histologically by the destruction of striatal neurons and clinically by increasing mobility abnormalities and dementia. All portions of the body move jerkily, hyperkinetically, and occasionally in a dystonic manner (chorea); affected people may eventually develop parkinsonism with bradykinesia and stiffness. The average course of the illness is around 15 years before death because of its persistent progression.

 

The polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat expansion illnesses have their origins in Huntington disease. The HD gene, which is found on chromosome 4p16.3, produces the 348-kD huntingtin protein.

 

A section of CAG repeats in the gene's first exon encodes a polyglutamine region near the protein's N terminus. The repeat is present in 6 to 35 copies in normal HD genes; when the number of repeats is increased beyond this level it is associated with disease.

 

There is an inverse relationship between repeat number and age of onset, such that longer repeats are associated with earlier onset.

 

The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is loss of function type of mutation: This is incorrect. Huntington's disease is caused by a gain-of-function mutation due to the expansion of the CAG repeat in the huntingtin gene, not by a loss-of-function mutation.

 

Option C. There are abnormal repeats of CUG: This is incorrect. The trinucleotide repeat involved in Huntington's disease is CAG, not CUG. CUG repeats are associated with other genetic disorders, such as myotonic dystrophy.

 

Option D. Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6: This is incorrect. The genetic mutation causing Huntington's disease is located on chromosome 4p16.3, not chromosome 6.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

choices.text: Waxy cast
RBC cast
WBC cast
Maltese cross cast

questions.text: During rounds, you come across the urinalysis report of the 30-year-old male diagnosed with Fabry's disease. What type of urinary casts would you expect to see in the report? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maltese cross cast

 

Maltese cross urinary casts are seen in a patient diagnosed with Fabry's disease.

 

Urine analysis in Fabry's disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance.

 

 

Maltese cross birefringence has also been described in:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans, cholesterol ester storage disease, babesiosis, and in urine sediments of a patient with nephrotic syndrome and erythropoietic protoporphyria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxy cast: Waxy casts are typically seen in chronic kidney disease and are associated with severe tubular atrophy and stasis of urine flow. They do not exhibit a Maltese cross pattern.

 

Option B. RBC cast: RBC casts are indicative of glomerular injury, such as in glomerulonephritis, and are not associated with Fabry's disease.

 

Option C. WBC cast: WBC casts are typically seen in conditions like pyelonephritis or interstitial nephritis, where there is inflammation involving the renal tubules or interstitium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maltese cross casts in urinalysis are indicative of Fabry's disease due to the presence of glycolipid-laden renal tubular cells. These casts show a characteristic birefringent pattern under polarized light.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in a female with dysuria and vesicles for which she underwent an examination that revealed the presence of cells as shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The image shown is a Tzanck smear, which is often used to diagnose infections caused by herpes viruses. The Tzanck smear reveals characteristic nuclear changes, including nuclear molding, margination of chromatin, and multinucleated giant cells, which are hallmark findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.

 

Patients with HSV typically present with vesicular lesions on the genitalia accompanied by dysuria and pain. The infection involves the fusion of epithelial cells, leading to the appearance of multinucleated giant cells, a distinctive feature seen on Tzanck smears.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. It presents with frothy discharge and vaginal itching but does not produce vesicular lesions or the cytological features seen in HSV.

 

Option C. Human papilloma virus (HPV): HPV causes genital warts and is associated with cervical dysplasia and cancer. It does not produce vesicular lesions or characteristic changes like multinucleated giant cells seen in HSV.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections are characterized by large cells with prominent intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions, often described as "owl's eye" appearance. This differs from the nuclear molding and margination seen in HSV infections.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus infection is identified by multinucleated giant cells, nuclear molding, and margination on Tzanck smear, distinguishing it from other genital infections.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. Ultrasound revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Papillary cancer of thyroid

 

The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

 

Histologically, the following features are present

 

  1. Papillary pattern - Papillae composed of fibrovascular stalk and covered by single layer of tumor cells is the predominant feature. Papillae are often accompanied by follicles.
  2. Tumor cells. The tumor cells have characteristic nuclear features due to dispersed nuclear chromatin imparting it ground glass or optically clear appearance and clear or oxyphilic cytoplasm also called Orphan Annie nuclei.
  3. Invasion - Invade the capsule and intra-thyroid lymphatics
  4. Psammoma bodies - Small, concentric, calcified spherules called psammoma bodies in the stroma.

 

Papillary carcinoma thyroid microscopy shows branching papillae having fibrovascular stalk covered by a single layer of cuboidal cells having ground nuclei. Colloid-filled follicles and sloid sheets of tumor cells are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary cancer of thyroid: This cancer arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid and is associated with elevated calcitonin levels. Histologically, it shows a solid growth pattern with amyloid deposits, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Follicular cancer of thyroid: This type of thyroid cancer typically shows a follicular growth pattern with invasion into blood vessels or the capsule. The cells do not have the distinct nuclear features (Orphan Annie nuclei) seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Thyroglossal cyst: This is a benign cystic lesion that usually presents as a midline neck mass that moves with swallowing or tongue protrusion. It does not present with a nodule in the thyroid gland or the histological features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by Orphan Annie nuclei, psammoma bodies, and a papillary architecture, which are key diagnostic features.

questions.text: Crohn’s disease in comparison to ulcerative colitis is least likely to show which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continuous involvement of the gut

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), but they have distinct pathological and clinical features.

 

Key Features of Crohn's Disease:

 

  • Segmental involvement: Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, segmental involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, known as "skip lesions." This contrasts with ulcerative colitis, which typically involves continuous, uninterrupted inflammation of the colon.

 

Continuous Involvement of the Gut:

 

This feature is typical of ulcerative colitis, where the inflammation is continuous and starts from the rectum extending proximally in a continuous manner without skipping any areas. In Crohn's disease, the inflammation is discontinuous, with normal areas interspersed between inflamed regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced risk of colon cancer: This is true for Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, as the risk of progression to malignancy is generally lower, especially for non-colonic Crohn's.

 

Option C. Higher risk of perianal fistula: Crohn's disease has a higher risk of perianal complications, including fistulas, due to the transmural nature of its inflammation.

 

Option D. Rarely present with daily hematochezia: Daily hematochezia is less common in Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, which is more likely to cause continuous bloody diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Continuous involvement of the gut is least likely to be associated with Crohn's disease, which is characterized by segmental, patchy inflammation known as "skip lesions."

 

Key Differences Between Crohn’s Disease & Ulcerative Colitis:

choices.text: Islam needle

questions.text: A bone marrow biopsy was indicated in a patient with unexplained anemia and following needle was used to extract specimen. Identify the instrument: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Klima needle

 

The given instrument is a Klima needle used for bone marrow biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salah's needle: Salah's needle is another type of biopsy needle but is different in design and is not commonly used for bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle: The Jamshidi needle is also used for bone marrow biopsies and is one of the most commonly used tools for this purpose. However, it has a different appearance compared to the Klima needle.

 

Option D. Islam needle: This needle is used for certain types of biopsies but is not typically associated with bone marrow biopsy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Interstitial cystitis
Polypoid cystitis

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and histopathology image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia.

 

  • Malakoplakia is a rare condition of unknown etiology primarily affecting the urinary bladder. It is likely associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis by macrophages. It is more commonly observed in immunocompromised patients and transplant recipients.
  • On cystoscopy, malakoplakia appears as multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone. The lesions are soft, flat, and slightly raised, with sizes ranging from 0.5 to 5 cm.
  • Histopathologically, malakoplakia shows massive accumulation of foamy macrophages, multinucleate giant cells, and lymphocytes.
  • Foamy macrophages contain granular cytoplasm that is PAS-positive.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, characterized by cytoplasmic laminated concretions of calcium phosphate, are seen within macrophages.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies represent lysosomes filled with partially digested debris of bacteria, resulting from defective phagocytosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pain and frequent, urgent urination. It does not present with yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis presents with polypoid or papillary projections in the bladder, often due to chronic irritation, such as long-term catheter use. It does not show the specific histopathological features of malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder characterized by symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency of urination. The cystoscopy findings would typically show an inflamed, red mucosa, not yellow-white plaques.

 

Educational objective:

 

Malakoplakia is characterized by multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone, as seen on cystoscopy, and histopathological findings of foamy macrophages with PAS-positive cytoplasm and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. This condition is associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis, commonly affecting immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in OPD with a swelling in his neck. Given below is the histopathological image. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma of thyroid

 

The histopathological image shows Amyloid deposition and nests of polygonal cells, which is suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid. This type of cancer is associated with the presence of amyloid deposits, which can be seen as pinkish extracellular material in the histological sections. These amyloid deposits are derived from calcitonin produced by the neoplastic C-cells (parafollicular cells).

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland, which produce calcitonin. The histopathological hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, often stained with Congo red, showing apple-green birefringence under polarized light. Additionally, the tumor cells are often arranged in nests or sheets, with polygonal or spindle-shaped cells.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Characterized by the formation of papillae and distinct nuclear features like Orphan-Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and pseudoinclusions. It typically does not have amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid: Typically shows follicles filled with colloid, and Hurthle cells may be present. This type is also known for hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid: A highly aggressive form of thyroid cancer, characterized by pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and a lack of differentiated features seen in other thyroid carcinomas. It also lacks the amyloid deposits seen in medullary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects both males and females, and it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that males and females have an equal chance of inheriting the disorder from a parent, which is consistent with the family history provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: This is a X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are typically carriers unless under rare circumstances.

 

Option C. Christmas Disease (Hemophilia B): Similar to Hemophilia A, this condition is also X-linked recessive, predominantly affecting males.

 

Option D. Factor 12 Deficiency: This is a much rarer condition and usually does not lead to significant bleeding issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome
Villous adenoma
Juvenile polyp

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

 

  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations. These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable. The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five. When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps. The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puetz Jegher syndrome: Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are neoplastic and present with a different histopathological pattern of finger-like or villous projections.

 

  • They are usually found in older adults and are not typically associated with painless rectal bleeding in children.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that can range from small polyps to large sessile lesions.

 

  • They do not exhibit the cystically dilated glands seen in juvenile polyps and are also more common in older adults.

 

Note - Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of rectal polyps in children under five, characterized by cystically dilated crypts and glands, and often present with painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and cough. A mass is noted at the lower lobe periphery of the lung. A diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma is made. What will be the biopsy finding? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Thyroid transcription factor-1
  2. P40
  3. Napsin A
  4. Chromogranin
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3

 

In the context of lung adenocarcinoma, particularly in a chronic smoker presenting with a peripheral lung mass, specific markers on the biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

1. Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1): TTF-1 is a nuclear transcription factor commonly expressed in lung adenocarcinoma and is used as a diagnostic marker to differentiate primary lung adenocarcinoma from other types of lung cancer.

 

3. Napsin A: Napsin A is another marker often expressed in lung adenocarcinoma, associated with the protein's role in the proteolytic processing of surfactant precursors in the lung.

 

These markers are both used to identify lung adenocarcinoma, particularly in cases where the tumor presents in the lung periphery.

 

Other options:

 

2. P40: P40 is a marker associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, not adenocarcinoma. Its presence would suggest a different subtype of lung cancer.

 

4. Chromogranin: Chromogranin is a marker used in neuroendocrine tumors, such as small cell lung cancer, and is not typically found in lung adenocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffering from persistent fatigue and lymph node enlargement visits the outpatient department. Examination of his peripheral smear reveals the presence of smudge cells. To further establish a diagnosis, what additional investigations will you conduct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly man presenting with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy and revelation of smudge cells on peripheral smear suggests a diagnosis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. Flow cytometry is the investigation of choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is typically used for detecting specific genetic mutations or translocations but is not the primary diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities, such as deletions or translocations. While useful, it is not the first-line investigation for diagnosing CLL.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can reveal chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL, such as deletion 13q, but is typically used in conjunction with other tests like flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:


Flow cytometry is the primary diagnostic tool for confirming Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, particularly in cases where smudge cells are identified on a peripheral smear.

questions.text: Identify the disorder with X-linked dominant inheritance: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

 

Rett syndrome:

 

 

Other examples of XLD disorders include Vitamin D Independent Rickets, Aicardi Syndrome, Hypophosphatemic Rickets, Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD): Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in X linked recessive pattern. It is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene and predominantly affects boys, leading to progressive muscle weakness and wasting.

Option C. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, leading to motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.           

 

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis / Bournville disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder most commonly seen in girls, characterized by microcephaly, regression of motor milestones, developmental delay, and stereotyped movements.

questions.text: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asbestosis

 

This clinical scenario and image showing typical asbestos bodies are suggestive of asbestosis.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • Non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • Presence of characteristic asbestos bodies - asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma, a rare and aggressive cancer of the pleura.

 

 

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell – shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Silicosis: Another type of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of silica dust, but it does not produce asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: An infectious disease primarily caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, characterized by granulomas and caseating necrosis, not by the presence of asbestos bodies.

 

Option D. Mesothelioma: While asbestos exposure is a risk factor for mesothelioma, the histological appearance in this case is more indicative of asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is identified by the presence of characteristic asbestos bodies within the lung tissue, which are asbestos fibers coated with glycoproteins and hemosiderin, and it is commonly associated with asbestos exposure in occupational settings.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1309

questions.text:
Which of the following is the best investigation for aneuploidy? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. In Situ Hybridization
  2. Conventional cytogenetics 
  3. PCR
  4. Sanger sequencing
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A & B

 

For the detection of aneuploidy, both In Situ Hybridization (specifically FISH - Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best investigations. "FISH technique is an important technique which not only helps to detect the presence of microdeletions or an excess number of certain types of genes being expressed it also helps to detect the presence of specific chromosomal translocations.

 

Conventional cytogenetics, though more time-consuming than FISH, is still an effective method for aneuploidy detection. It involves visualizing the chromosomes under a microscope during cell division to count them and look for gross abnormalities.

 

Both techniques allow direct visualization of chromosomal material and can detect numerical abnormalities like aneuploidy. FISH is particularly valuable because it can rapidly detect common aneuploidies like trisomy 21, 18, 13 within 24-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C & D (PCR and Sanger sequencing): These techniques are not the best for detecting aneuploidy. PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for analyzing specific DNA sequences and mutations, but they cannot effectively detect changes in chromosome number.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best techniques for detecting aneuploidy (abnormal chromosome numbers), while PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for specific sequence analysis but not aneuploidy detection.

questions.text: All of the following are responsible for Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INF- y  

 

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is associated with a transient, marked rise in circulating tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF alpha), interleukin 6 (IL-6) and interleukin 8 (IL-8).

 

It is an inflammatory reaction that can occur after treatment for syphilis.

 

The symptoms usually begin 2 hours from the administration of the antibiotic and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TNF alpha: Directly involved in the inflammatory response associated with JHR.

 

Option B. IL-6: Also directly involved in JHR, promoting inflammatory processes.

 

Option C. IL-8: Plays a role in recruiting neutrophils to sites of infection, contributing to the inflammatory reaction in JHR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is primarily driven by a surge in pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF alpha, IL-6, and IL-8, but not by INF-γ.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTH carcinoma

 

MEN2B includes "Medullary thyroid cancer, Pheochromocytoma, Other extra features → Marfanoid habitus, Mucosal neuromas." Parathyroid involvement (PTH carcinoma) is not a component of MEN2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Epithelial mesenchymal transcription is mediated by which transcription factors? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SNAIL/TWIST

 

Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a crucial process in cancer metastasis where epithelial cells lose their cell-cell adhesion and gain migratory properties. This process is primarily mediated by SNAIL and TWIST transcription factors. These factors cause:

 

  • Decreased expression of E-cadherin (epithelial marker)
  • Increased expression of mesenchymal markers like vimentin and smooth muscle actin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cathepsin D

 

  • This is incorrect as cathepsin D is a protease involved in protein degradation
  • While it may play a role in tissue invasion, it's not a transcription factor mediating EMT

 

Option C. MMP-9 (Matrix Metalloprotease-9)

 

  • This is incorrect as MMP-9 is an enzyme involved in degrading extracellular matrix
  • It's important for invasion but doesn't mediate EMT transcription

 

Option D. TTF-1 (Thyroid Transcription Factor-1)

 

  • This is incorrect as TTF-1 is a transcription factor specific to thyroid and lung tissue development
  • It's not involved in EMT

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SNAIL and TWIST are the key transcription factors responsible for mediating epithelial-mesenchymal transition, a crucial step in cancer metastasis.

questions.text: For HbA1c sample, the vacutainer used contains which of the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EDTA

 

Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is measured to assess long-term glycemic control in diabetic patients. The preferred sample for HbA1c estimation is whole blood, and the anticoagulant used for this is EDTA.

 

  • EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is used because:
    • It prevents coagulation by chelating calcium.
    • It preserves RBC integrity, ensuring accurate measurement of glycosylated hemoglobin.
    • Lavender-top (Purple) vacutainers contain EDTA and are commonly used for HbA1c testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: 

 

  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant used therapeutically, not for blood collection.

 

Option B. Sodium Fluoride:

 

  • Used in gray-top vacutainers, primarily for glucose estimation, as it inhibits glycolysis.
  • Does not preserve RBCs well, so not used for HbA1c.

 

Option D. Heparin:

 

  • Used in green-top vacutainers, primarily for plasma-based tests (e.g., electrolytes, arterial blood gases).
  • Not used for HbA1c, as it does not preserve whole blood effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HbA1c estimation, EDTA (lavender-top vacutainer) is used because it prevents coagulation while preserving RBC integrity for accurate glycosylated hemoglobin measurement.

 

Vacutainer Vials and Their Uses

 

 

Sequence of blood Drawn - Chalo Bhai, Red yellow Green Light → Go

 

Culture Bottle – Blue – Red – Yellow – Green – Lavender – Grey

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulointerstitial nephritis

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis, also known as acute allergic interstitial nephritis, is often caused by an allergic reaction to medications such as antibiotics. In this scenario, the patient had a fever and sore throat and was subsequently treated with antibiotics, likely from the penicillin group. Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics are common culprits in causing type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, leading to the presence of eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria). This condition is also associated with the presence of WBC casts in the urine, indicating inflammation of the renal interstitium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with RBC casts rather than WBC casts and does not involve eosinophiluria. It follows a streptococcal infection and involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli.

 

Option C. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to glomerulonephritis. It is not typically associated with eosinophiluria and primarily presents with RBC casts.

 

Option D. Rhabdomyolysis: Rhabdomyolysis involves the breakdown of muscle tissue, leading to the release of muscle contents into the bloodstream, including myoglobin, which can cause renal damage. It is characterized by elevated creatine kinase levels and does not present with eosinophiluria or WBC casts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

choices.text: Total lack of natural killer cells
Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describes the immunological anomaly associated with the absence of CD40 in B cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM

 

The absence of CD40 and its deficiency in B cells results in Hyper IgM syndrome. This condition is characterized by a reduction in IgG levels and an elevation in IgM levels.

 

HYPER IGM SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total lack of natural killer cells: This is not associated with CD40 deficiency but rather with other immune disorders like severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

Option B. Lack of CD8 mediated cytotoxicity: CD40/CD40L interactions do not directly affect CD8 T cells. CD8 mediated cytotoxicity is more related to T cell receptor function and MHC class I interactions.

 

Option D. Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections: While CD40 deficiency can lead to an increased susceptibility to infections, neutrophil function is not directly impaired by the absence of CD40. This function is more related to chronic granulomatous disease or other neutrophil defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by an increased level of IgM and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins like IgG, due to a defect in the CD40/CD40L interaction necessary for immunoglobulin class switching.

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells)

questions.text: A child is brought to OPD with multiple skin lesions over the inner thigh and genital areas. Patient reported that it initially started as macule and later developed to become nodules. On examination, you noticed that some nodules have central umbilication. Microscopy finding is shown below. Identify the finding: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Henderson-Patterson bodies

 

Clinical history along with histological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies suggests a diagnosis of Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus infection of the skin and the mucous membranes.

 

There are four types of molluscum contagiosum viruses (MCVs), MCV-1 to -4, with MCV-1 being the most prevalent and MCV-2 being most often sexually transmitted.

 

The infections are common in young children between 2 and 12 years of age and are transmitted through direct contact or shared articles (e.g., towels).

 

Molluscum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs. In adults, molluscum infections are typically sexually transmitted and affect the genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.

 

The average incubation period is 6 weeks.

 

Diagnosis is based on the characteristic clinical appearance of pearly, domeshaped papules with a dimpled center. The papules measure 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and their central waxy core contains cells with intracytoplasmic viral inclusions called as Molluscum bodies or Henderson Patterson bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells): These are typically seen in herpesvirus infections, such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and are not related to molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option B. Donovan bodies: These are characteristic of granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Koilocytes: These are squamous epithelial cells that have undergone specific changes due to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, are pathognomonic for molluscum contagiosum, a poxvirus infection.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presented in OPD with complaints of fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, lymphadenopathy was present. They were non-tender, rubbery in consistency, located in the supraclavicular and inguinal regions on both sides. Peripheral smear showed the presence of bi-nucleated cells. Which markers can be identified in this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. CD15
  2. CD30
  3. CD19
  4. CD3
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

Clinical history and the histopathological examination showing bi-nucleated cells, called Reed Sternberg cells points to a diagnosis of Hodgkins lymphoma. RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+.

 

Reed-Sternberg cells marker –

 

  • CDI5
  • CD30 (most sensitive)
  • PAX-5 (most SPECIFIC)

 

 

Reed Sternberg Cells are non-specific since it is seen in conditions like:

 

  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Non- Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Infection Mononucleosis
  • Sarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

CD19 (3) and CD3 (4): These markers are associated with B and T cells, respectively. CD19 is a B-cell marker, and CD3 is a T-cell marker. They are not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells characteristically express CD15 and CD30, making these markers essential for diagnosis.

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia) that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: The Philadelphia chromosome is associated with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and would not be the primary investigation in a case where polycythemia is suspected.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: While JAK2 mutations are common in Polycythemia Vera, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes. If primary polycythemia is suspected after assessing erythropoietin levels, testing for JAK2 mutations would be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This test would be more relevant if there is a need to assess bone marrow fibrosis or other marrow abnormalities, but it is not the first-line investigation in the context of suspected polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected polycythemia, particularly in patients from high-altitude areas, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes of polycythemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Page No.  1161, 1242

questions.text: A male patient suffers a trauma and is being brought to the emergency room of a hospital. Since he needs an emergency lifesaving transfusion, which of the following can be safely transfused in him?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) O negative

 

In emergency situations where a lifesaving transfusion is needed, and there is no time to determine the patient's blood type, O negative blood is considered the universal donor and can be safely transfused to any patient. This is because O negative blood does not have any A, B, or Rh antigens on the surface of the red blood cells, minimizing the risk of an adverse reaction.

 

However, it is important to note that O negative blood is often in short supply. In extremely critical situations, such as with an older male or a postmenopausal female, or when O negative blood is not available, O positive blood may be used as an alternative. O positive blood can be safely transfused to males and females who are not of childbearing age, as the presence of Rh antigen can cause issues in future pregnancies for females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive: A positive blood type contains A and Rh antigens and can only be safely transfused to individuals with A positive, AB positive, or compatible types. It is not a universal donor.

 

Option B. AB negative: AB negative blood can only be given to AB negative or AB positive recipients due to the presence of both A and B antigens. It is also not a universal donor.

 

Option D. O positive: While O positive blood can be given in critical situations, it is not the first choice for universal emergency transfusions due to the presence of Rh antigen, which can cause complications in Rh-negative individuals, especially females of childbearing age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emergency transfusion situations where blood type is unknown, O negative blood is the safest option due to its lack of A, B, and Rh antigens, making it universally compatible.

questions.text: All of the following features are observed in pleomorphic adenoma except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perineural invasion

 

Perineural invasion is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma.

 

 

Note - Perineural invasion is seen in malignant salivary gland tumors like adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myoepithelial cells: Present in pleomorphic adenomas, contributing to the tumor's mixed epithelial and mesenchymal characteristics.

 

Option B. Keratin pearls: While not typically a feature of pleomorphic adenomas, the presence of keratin can be associated with the epithelial component. However, keratin pearls are more characteristic of squamous cell carcinomas.

 

Option C. Chondroid differentiation: A hallmark of pleomorphic adenomas, where the tumor shows cartilaginous differentiation, often contributing to its benign nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Pleomorphic adenomas are characterized by a mixture of epithelial and mesenchymal components, including myoepithelial cells and chondroid differentiation, but they do not exhibit perineural invasion, which is more typical of malignant salivary gland tumors.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1436-1437

choices.text: Aschoff's bodies
Epithelioid granuloma
Granulomatous vasculitis

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

 

Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation. Aschoff's bodies are the most likely lesion in the histopathological slide.

 

Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues. Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epithelioid granuloma: Epithelioid granulomas are associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. They do not have the characteristic Anitschkow cells seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option  C. Granulomatous vasculitis: Granulomatous vasculitis is characterized by granulomas in the walls of blood vessels, which is seen in conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis. It does not match the histological description of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale: Granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with genital ulcers and Donovan bodies on histology, which is unrelated to the cardiac findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

choices.text: Alternative RNA splicing

questions.text: Due to which phenomenon, B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alternative RNA splicing

 

B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to alternative RNA splicing.

 

Alternative splicing is the process that selectively removes introns or exons, or parts thereof, to generate multiple messenger RNAs (mRNAs) from a single precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA).

 

Humoral immunity is mediated by antibodies, which are produced by B lymphocytes.

 

Upon maturation, B lymphocytes produce IgM as the first type of immunoglobulin, followed by immunoglobulin IgG, IgE, and IgA, as a result of irreversible rearrangement of the immunoglobulin gene after activation.

 

In contrast, the IgM-to-IgD transition is produced through alternative splicing of a long primary mRNA transcript from the Ig heavy chain gene, IGH. The nuclear RNA-binding protein, HuR, is well known for its function in mRNA splicing and nuclear export.

 

Other options:

 

Options A. Somatic hypermutation and C. Affinity maturation: Affinity maturation is the process by which antibodies gain increased affinity, avidity, and anti-pathogen activity and is the result of somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled to selection for antigen binding.

 

Option D. Allelic exclusion: Allelic exclusion is a process by which only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other allele is silenced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

B cells express both IgM and IgD through alternative RNA splicing, allowing the simultaneous expression of these two immunoglobulins.

questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral small streak ovaries

 

The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen

 

  • Missing an entire X chromosome - this results in a 45X0 karyotype.
  • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes
  • Mosaics - they will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45×/46X, ¡(X)(q10).

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

Normal secondary sex characteristics do not develop during puberty. The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and pubic hair is scarce. In adults, short stature and amenorrhea are especially important in establishing the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: While Turner syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, such as coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, aortic dissection is less common in children and typically occurs in adults with significant aortic disease.

 

Option B. Subluxation of lens: Subluxation of the lens is a feature of Marfan syndrome, not Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Mitral valve prolapse: Mitral valve prolapse is more commonly associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Turner syndrome is more characteristically associated with left-sided heart defects like coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and streak ovaries, leading to primary ovarian insufficiency, infertility, and amenorrhea. The diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping, and the most likely finding in Turner syndrome patients is bilateral small streak ovaries.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE

 

The given clinical features suggest a anaphylactic reaction, a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, and is mediated by immunoglobulin E.

 

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies.

 

It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.

 

Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (such as the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g. peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g. those in bee venom).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is mainly involved in mucosal immunity and does not play a primary role in type I hypersensitivity or anaphylactic reactions.

 

Option C. IgM: IgM is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response but is not involved in allergic or type I hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is involved in various immune responses, including type II and type III hypersensitivity reactions, but not in the immediate hypersensitivity reaction that leads to anaphylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgE is the immunoglobulin responsible for mediating type I hypersensitivity reactions, such as anaphylaxis, which can occur in response to bee stings or other allergens.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 373

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports Hemoglobin 17 gm%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia), that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: This test is relevant in diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not polycythemia. While the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes and metamyelocytes) could suggest a myeloproliferative disorder, the patient's clinical presentation and high hemoglobin level are more consistent with polycythemia, making erythropoietin testing a more appropriate next step.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: Testing for the JAK2 mutation is crucial in confirming a diagnosis of PCV. However, before proceeding to this test, it is important to measure erythropoietin levels to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. If erythropoietin levels are low, JAK2 mutation analysis would then be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This investigation is used to evaluate bone marrow fibrosis, which can occur in myeloproliferative disorders like PCV. However, it is not the first-line investigation in this scenario. The erythropoietin level is a less invasive test that provides critical information to guide further diagnostic steps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin levels should be measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. In cases of polycythemia vera, erythropoietin levels are typically low due to constitutive JAK2 signaling, while secondary polycythemia is associated with high erythropoietin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Pg 1161, 1242

questions.text: Which fixation technique is used for fat in the histopathological examination? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frozen section

 

Identification of neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues may require fresh smears or sometimes cryostat sections of tissue. 

 

Rapid freezing makes the tissue sample firmer and ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned.

 

Cryostat machine temperature ranges from 0°C to -35°C. Most of the tissue can be sectioned between -15°C to -25°C. Tissue samples with high water content can be sectioned at a higher temperature. The tissues with high fat content are cut at a lower temperature.

 

The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain.

 

It is used in the following conditions:

 

  • Fat emboli in lung tissue
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Sebaceous gland tumors of the skin
  • Lipid-rich carcinomas

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IHC (Immunohistochemistry): This technique is used for detecting specific proteins within tissue sections but is not specifically used for fat preservation or visualization.

 

Option C. Liquid paraffin: Liquid paraffin is most commonly used for the fixation technique in the histopathological examination. It involves the fixation of tissues using formalin and subsequent embedding in paraffin wax. This technique allows for long-term preservation of tissue morphology and cellular details, making it the standard preservation procedure.

 

Option D. Formalin fixed: Formalin fixation is the standard method for preserving general tissue morphology but is not ideal for fat preservation, as it can dissolve lipid content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcoholic formalin is the most commonly used fixation technique for preserving and examining fat in histopathological sections.

 

Liquid paraffin is the most commonly used embedding agent.

choices.text: Transferrin saturation
RBC protoporphyrin
Total iron binding capacity
Serum transferrin receptors

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

 

Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin (the protein that transports iron in the blood) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the transferrin saturation is decreased because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

It is important to note that in a patient with iron deficiency anemia, there is increased TIBC as well as increased RBC Protoporphyrin levels and the number of serum transferrin receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC protoporphyrin: This is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway. In iron deficiency anemia, the lack of iron means that protoporphyrin accumulates, as it cannot be converted into heme. Therefore, RBC protoporphyrin levels are increased.

 

Option C. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): This is a measure of the total capacity of the blood to bind iron with transferrin. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased as the body produces more transferrin in an attempt to capture more iron from the diet and the body’s stores.

 

Option D. Serum transferrin receptors: These receptors are present on the surface of cells and are involved in the uptake of transferrin-bound iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the number of these receptors increases as the body tries to increase iron uptake from the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following microscopic finding with the type of tumor? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b  

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Pulmonary infarction
Diffuse alveolar damage
Endothelial injury

questions.text: The most common lung finding in COVID 19 infection is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Diffuse alveolar damage may be seen in patients suffering from COVID-19.

 

COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include:

 

  1. Incipient pulmonary damage in early-stage disease with intraalveolar edema, endothelial necrosis, microthrombosis, and endothelialitis.
  2. Pneumocyte type 2 hyperplasia in exudative phase
  3. Multiple intraalveolar giant cells in exudative phase
  4. Hyaline membranes and solid fibrin deposits in exudative phase
  5. Thrombosis in small- to medium-sized vessels in early-stage lung disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary infarction: While pulmonary infarctions may occur due to thromboembolism, they are not the primary lung finding in COVID-19.

 

Option C. Endothelial injury: Endothelial injury does occur in COVID-19 and contributes to microvascular damage and thrombosis, but it is part of the broader picture of diffuse alveolar damage.

 

Option D. Fibrin clots: Fibrin clots are seen in COVID-19 as part of the coagulopathy associated with the disease, but they are secondary findings within the context of DAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common and significant lung finding in severe COVID-19 infection, leading to the clinical syndrome of ARDS.

choices.text: Myxoid liposarcoma
Spindle lipoma

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myxoid liposarcoma

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

The image shows a lot of ground substance, as well as some branching capillaries and immature adipocytes.

 

Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults, typically appearing in the fifth to sixth decade of life.

 

They are most commonly found in the proximal extremities (deep soft tissues) and the retroperitoneum.

 

Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into four subtypes: 

 

  • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: resembles lipoma but contains uni- or multi-vacuolated lipoblasts. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-g15.
  • Myxoid liposarcoma: Most common histologic type. It is composed of monomorphic, fusiform or stellate cells representing primitive mesenchymal cells, lying dispersed in mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance. Occasional tumor giant cells may be present. Prominent meshwork of capillaries forming chicken-wire patterns is a conspicuous feature. It is associated with t (12;16).
  • Round cell liposarcoma is composed of uniform, round to oval cells having fine multi vacuolated cytoplasm with central hyperchromatic nuclei. Round cell liposarcoma may resemble a signet-ring carcinoma but mucin stains help in distinguishing the two.
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: highly undifferentiated and the most anaplastic type. There are numerous large tumor giant cells and bizarre lipoblasts. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoma: This is incorrect. Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue and do not show the histological features or molecular translocation (t (12;16)) seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option C. Spindle lipoma: This is incorrect. Spindle cell lipomas are benign tumors composed of spindle-shaped cells mixed with mature adipocytes and do not have the mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance or the t (12;16) translocation seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option D. Polymorphic lipoma: This is incorrect. Polymorphic lipomas are also benign and do not exhibit the characteristic histological features or molecular markers of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxoid liposarcoma is the most common histologic type of liposarcoma, characterized by a mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance, a prominent capillary network forming chicken-wire patterns, and the presence of the translocation t (12;16).

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a bone marrow aspirate having the finding as shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic myeloid leukemia

 

The image shows a characteristic cell known as a Gaucher cell, identifiable by its distinctive "crumpled tissue paper" or "wrinkled" cytoplasm appearance and blue staining.

 

 

Gaucher cells are lipid-laden histiocytes seen in Gaucher disease, but similar cells, called pseudo-Gaucher cells, can also be found in hematological malignancies, particularly in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). In CML, the presence of pseudo-Gaucher cells is a response to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism, making this finding more associated with CML than with other forms of leukemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukemia: While AML may show abnormal blast cells in the bone marrow, it is not typically associated with Gaucher or pseudo-Gaucher cells.

 

Option B. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia: ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts and does not typically present with pseudo-Gaucher cells in the bone marrow.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia: CLL involves mature lymphocytes, and pseudo-Gaucher cells are not a typical finding in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudo-Gaucher cells, characterized by a crumpled cytoplasm appearance, are often seen in chronic myeloid leukemia due to increased cellular turnover and abnormal lipid metabolism

choices.text: Release of reactive oxygen species and free radicles
Suppression of angiogenesis
Inhibition of IL2, IL4, IL5

questions.text: Which of these options is not a mechanism contributing to thalidomide's teratogenic effects? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibition of IL2, IL4, IL5

 

The teratogenic effects of thalidomide arise from a combination of factors such as oxidative stress, inhibition of blood vessel formation (anti-angiogenesis), and its interaction with a specific protein known as cereblon. This protein, CRBN, plays a significant role in the formation of cerebral tissues. Notably, its presence in various brain regions, including the hippocampus, is linked to functions like memory and learning processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenic effects are caused by several mechanisms, which include:

 

Option A. Release of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals: Thalidomide induces oxidative stress, leading to cellular damage during development, which is one of the key factors in its teratogenicity. ROS and free radicals cause damage to cellular components, leading to malformations.

 

Option B. Suppression of angiogenesis: Thalidomide inhibits the formation of new blood vessels, a critical process during embryogenesis. This suppression leads to improper development of limbs and organs, contributing significantly to the teratogenic effects seen in affected fetuses.

 

Option C. Cereblon binding: Thalidomide’s interaction with cereblon (CRBN), a protein crucial for limb and organ development, is another major mechanism of its teratogenicity. The binding of thalidomide to CRBN disrupts its normal function, leading to developmental abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide’s teratogenicity is primarily due to oxidative stress, inhibition of angiogenesis, and binding to cereblon, rather than the inhibition of interleukins IL2, IL4, and IL5.

questions.text: An individual undergoes a bone marrow examination which shows the presence of the cells as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely enzyme defect associated with this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The presence of gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease. It is caused by deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher's Disease:

 

  • Pathology: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside into glucose and ceramide.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bone pain or fractures.
  • Histopathology: Gaucher cells are macrophages filled with lipid-laden lysosomes. These cells have a characteristic crumpled paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hexosaminidase: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by a cherry-red spot on the macula.

 

Option C. Alpha 1,4 glucosidase: Deficiency causes Pompe disease, characterized by glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.

 

Option D. Galactosidase: Deficiency causes Fabry disease, characterized by angiokeratomas, acroparesthesia, and renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance in a bone marrow examination are indicative of Gaucher's disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher Disease Overview:

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling and difficulty in swallowing food. Histopathological examination of the swelling shows increased nests of cells with amyloid deposition. Which of the following is the cell of origin of this mass?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parafollicular cells

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is the type of thyroid cancer associated with increased nests of cells and amyloid deposition. MTC arises from the parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid. These cells produce calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The presence of amyloid in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin, which can be detected as amyloid material in histopathological examinations. This type of thyroid cancer is distinct from other forms such as papillary, follicular, or anaplastic thyroid carcinomas, which originate from follicular cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial cells: Incorrect. Endothelial cells line blood vessels and are not associated with thyroid tumors that show amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular cells: Incorrect. Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid cancers, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hurthle cells: Incorrect. Hurthle cells are a variant of follicular cells and can be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, another type of thyroid cancer, but not in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, characterized by nests of cells and amyloid deposition, arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid.

questions.text: What is the content of given vacutainer? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper, hence it contains clot activator

 

Red stopper plastic tubes contain silica as a clot activator.

 

The tubes are inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Use – Serum Analysis, Serology tests, Blood banks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: EDTA is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a lavender stopper for hematological tests such as complete blood counts (CBC).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: This anticoagulant is used in light blue stopper tubes, primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and APTT.

 

Option C. Na-heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a green stopper, commonly for plasma biochemistry tests.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a bone marrow aspirate having the finding as shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase defect

 

The image shows a Gaucher cell, which is characterized by its large size, crumpled tissue paper-like cytoplasm, and abnormal lysosomal accumulation.

 

Gaucher cells are seen in Gaucher's disease, which is the most common lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme defect leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within the cells, resulting in the characteristic appearance seen in bone marrow aspirates.

 

Gaucher's disease presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and hematologic abnormalities due to the accumulation of these lipid-laden cells in the bone marrow, liver, and spleen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphingomyelinase defect: This enzyme defect is seen in Niemann-Pick disease, not Gaucher's disease. Niemann-Pick cells are large foamy cells filled with sphingomyelin and cholesterol, which have a distinctly different appearance compared to Gaucher cells.

 

Option C. Galactosidase defect: This refers to a deficiency in alpha-galactosidase A, which is associated with Fabry's disease, a lysosomal storage disorder that affects the skin, kidneys, heart, and nervous system, but does not produce Gaucher cells.

 

Option D. Hexosaminidase defect: A deficiency in hexosaminidase A is the cause of Tay-Sachs disease, which is characterized by a cherry-red spot on the retina and severe neurological impairment, without the presence of Gaucher cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher's disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder, caused by a glucocerebrosidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of Gaucher cells with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper-like appearance in bone marrow aspirates.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of TTP? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thrombosis

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a life-threatening condition caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the ADAMTS13 enzyme, which leads to widespread platelet aggregation and microvascular occlusions. The classic pentad of TTP includes:

 

1. Thrombocytopenia – Due to platelet consumption in small vessel thrombi.

 

2. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia – Formation of schistocytes due to red blood cell destruction in small vessels.

 

 

3. Neurological symptoms – Ranging from confusion, headaches, and seizures to strokes.

 

4. Renal dysfunction – Present in some cases due to microvascular damage.

 

5. Fever – A non-specific symptom due to systemic inflammation.

 

While platelet-rich thrombi are characteristic of TTP, clinical thrombosis (macrovascular thrombosis like DVT or pulmonary embolism) is not a typical feature. The pathogenesis involves microvascular platelet thrombi rather than large-vessel thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The classical pentad of TTP:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Fever
  • Neurological manifestations

choices.text: Routine Ha & E

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloidosis

 

The given image demonstrates Congo red stain showing Pink red appearance under normal light. This stain is used in diagnosis of Amyloidosis.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Elastic fibers: Elastic fibers can be demonstrated by Verhoeff-van Gieson Stain.

 

 

Option B. Routine H & E: Routine H & E is done by Hematoxylin and eosin stain. The hematoxylin stains cell nuclei a purplish blue, and eosin stains the extracellular matrix and cytoplasm pink.

 

 

Option D. Collagen: Collagen can be demonstrated by Masson trichrome stain. It gives blue color to the collagen, black color to nuclei and red to muscle present.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congo red staining, showing pink-red deposits under normal light, is characteristic of amyloid and is a key diagnostic tool for amyloidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins of human papilloma virus inactivates Rb gene? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E7

 

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with several cancers, including cervical cancer. HPV has two key oncoproteins, E6 and E7, that play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of cancer by inactivating tumor suppressor proteins.

 

E7 protein binds to and inactivates the Rb (Retinoblastoma) gene, which is a crucial tumor suppressor that controls cell cycle progression. By inactivating Rb, E7 disrupts the regulation of the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation, a hallmark of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6: Targets and degrades p53 but does not inactivate Rb. E6 promotes the degradation of p53, leading to the loss of its tumor suppressor functions, such as apoptosis and DNA repair.

 

Option C. L1: L1 is a major capsid protein of HPV involved in the assembly of the viral particle but does not have a role in inactivating tumor suppressor genes.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is a minor capsid protein involved in viral genome packaging and entry into host cells but does not inactivate tumor suppressor genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E7 protein of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the Rb gene, leading to disruption of the cell cycle and contributing to the development of cancer.

 

HPV Oncoproteins:

 

 

L1 protein is useful for making vaccine for HPV. (recent INICET ques)
