questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in Th1 response? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IL- 4

 

The cytokine not involved in TH1 response is IL-4.

 

T-cell response in this early stage is dominated by TH1 cells that produce IFN-γ, which stimulates macrophages to secrete high levels of the cytokines TNF, IL-1, and IL-6 that cause fever.

 

IL-12 is secreted by macrophages and promotes the proliferation of TH1 cells.

 

The 1 cells secrete IL-2 which activates natural killer cells (NK cells) and cytotoxic T cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma): IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma) is a key cytokine produced by Th1 cells. It activates macrophages and enhances their ability to destroy ingested microbes, and it also promotes the production of IgG antibodies that are essential for opsonization and phagocytosis of pathogens.

 

Option B. IL-2 (Interleukin-2): IL-2 (Interleukin-2) is produced by Th1 cells and plays a critical role in the activation and proliferation of T cells, including natural killer (NK) cells and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), which are crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

Option C. IL-12 (Interleukin-12): IL-12 (Interleukin-12) is produced by antigen-presenting cells (like dendritic cells and macrophages) and is essential for the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells. It also stimulates the production of IFN-γ by these Th1 cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A newborn presents with umbilical cord stump bleeding and a history of recurrent bleeding episodes. Laboratory results reveal normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, but a positive clot solubility test. What coagulation factor deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XIII

 

Factor XIII is essential for stabilizing fibrin clots by cross-linking fibrin monomers. A deficiency in Factor XIII leads to an unstable clot that dissolves easily, causing excessive bleeding despite normal routine coagulation tests such as PT (Prothrombin Time) and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time).

 

  • Clinical presentation:
    • Umbilical stump bleeding is a hallmark feature of Factor XIII deficiency, occurring shortly after birth.
    •  Recurrent bleeding episodes, including delayed hemorrhage after trauma or surgery.
    •  Intracranial hemorrhage can occur even without trauma.
    • Poor wound healing due to defective clot stabilization.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, as Factor XIII operates in the final step of clot formation and does not affect routine coagulation screening tests.
    • Positive clot solubility test: Clots dissolve in 5M urea or acetic acid within 24 hours due to the lack of cross-linking fibrin.

 

Thus, the positive clot solubility test in this patient strongly indicates Factor XIII deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hageman factor deficiency typically doesn't cause clinical bleeding
  • Would show prolonged aPTT on testing
  • Not associated with umbilical stump bleeding

 

Option B. Factor XI (Incorrect)

 

  • Would show prolonged aPTT
  • Not characteristically associated with umbilical cord bleeding
  • Clinical bleeding is usually mild and post-traumatic

 

Option C. Factor VIII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hemophilia A would show prolonged aPTT
  • While it causes bleeding, umbilical stump bleeding is not a characteristic presentation
  • Would not have a positive clot solubility test

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XIII deficiency presents with umbilical cord bleeding and shows normal PT, aPTT, and platelet count but positive clot solubility test due to unstable clot formation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a germ cell tumor of the ovary? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Granulosa cell tumor

 

Granulosa cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor, not a germ cell tumor of the ovary.

 

Granulosa cell tumors are derived from the sex cord-stromal cells of the ovary. These tumors are characterized by the presence of Call-Exner bodies and coffee bean-shaped nuclei. They are estrogen-secreting functional tumors that may present as precocious puberty, endometrial hyperplasia, or post-menopausal bleeding. The marker for granulosa cell tumors is Inhibin B, and they are associated with FOXL2 mutation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yolk sac tumor: This is incorrect because yolk sac tumor, also known as endodermal sinus tumor, is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. 

 

Yolk sac tumor (Endodermal sinus tumor)

 

  • 2nd MC malignant GCT
  • MC malignant ovarian tumor presenting in <4years
  • Histology: presence of Schiller Duval Body/Glomeruloid body
  • Tumor markers: AFP +, α1 AT +ve

 

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma: This is incorrect because dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is the ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma. 

  • Ovarian counterpart of seminoma
  • MC malignant GCT
  • Radiosensitive, chemo-sensitive tumor
  • Unilateral involvement mostly (85%)
  • Non-Functional tumor: hormones not secreted
  • Markers include transcription factors (OCT 3/4, NANOG, KiT) and enzymes (PLAP +, LDH, ß HCG but Normal AFP)

 

Option C. Choriocarcinoma: This is incorrect because choriocarcinoma can coexist with other germ cell tumors, as it can arise from either the ovary (germ cell origin) or the placenta (gestational trophoblastic disease)

 

  • It secretes beta-hCG, which serves as a tumor marker.
  • If it has ovarian origin: non- responsive to chemotherapy → poor prognosis 
  • If it has placenta origin excellent responsive to chemotherapy → good prognosis
  • Choriocarcinoma is known for early hematogenous spread and "cannon-ball" metastases to the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulosa cell tumor is classified as a sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary, not a germ cell tumor.

questions.text:
What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Disrupted cell membrane
  2. Induces inflammation
  3. Swelling of the cell
  4. Can be seen physiologically
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Necrosis is a form of cell injury that results in the premature death of cells in living tissue by autolysis. The following are the key characteristics of necrosis:

 

1. Disrupted cell membrane: Necrosis is characterized by the loss of cell membrane integrity, leading to the uncontrolled release of cellular contents into the extracellular space.

 

2. Induces inflammation: The release of cellular contents into the surrounding tissue causes an inflammatory response. This is a hallmark of necrosis, as the body reacts to the injury.

 

3. Swelling of the cell: In necrosis, cells typically swell and eventually rupture due to the loss of membrane integrity and the influx of water and ions.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Necrosis is never physiological: it always occurs as a result of pathological conditions. Unlike apoptosis, which is a programmed and regulated form of cell death, necrosis is unregulated and is usually detrimental to the organism.

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

FEATURES OF NECROSIS

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enhancer deletion

 

Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene. On the contrary, deletion of an enhancer would likely reduce the expression of the gene, potentially reducing its oncogenic potential, rather than increasing it.

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promoter insertion: Can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene by increasing gene transcription.

 

Option C. Gene amplification: Leads to an increased number of gene copies, enhancing gene product levels, and contributing to oncogenesis.

 

Option D. Point mutation: A common mechanism for converting proto-oncogenes to oncogenes by altering the protein product to make it constitutively active.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transformation of proto-oncogene (i.e., normal cell proliferation gene) to oncogenes (i.e., cancer cell proliferation gene) may occur by three mechanisms:

 

  1. Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription. 
  2. Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls.  Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22.
  3. Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region,  ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 549-551

questions.text: The scraping of a painless genital ulcer, when stained with Gram stain and viewed under the microscope, shows a gram-negative coccobacillus surrounded by neutrophils. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella granulomatis

 

The above description of a gram stain showing Gram-negative Coccobacillus surrounded by neutrophils is suggestive of Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium donovani)

 

Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted chronic inflammatory disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a minute, encapsulated, Coccobacillus.

 

 

Microscopically, the margin of the ulcer shows epithelial hyperplasia. The ulcer bed shows neutrophilic abscesses. The dermis and subcutaneous tissues are infiltrated by numerous histiocytes containing many bacteria called Donovan bodies, and lymphocytes, plasma cells and neutrophils. These organisms are best demonstrated by silver impregnation techniques.

 

Klebsiella granulomatis is difficult to culture and diagnosis needs visualization of dark-staining Donovan bodies on tissue crush preparation or biopsy. The organisms are demonstrable in Giemsa-stained smears of the exudate as a minute, encapsulated Coccobacilli (Donovan bodies) in macrophages.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlamydia trachomatis and Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Both are gram-negative diplococci, not coccobacilli, making them inconsistent with the gram-negative coccobacillus described in the question.

 

Option B. Hemophilus ducreyi: This bacterium, which causes chancroid, typically presents with a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain and is associated with painful genital ulcers, not the painless ulcer described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 664

choices.text: Increased formation of Heinz body
Males and females can be affected
Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about a patient with G6PD deficiency?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects the red blood cells' ability to handle oxidative stress.

 

This is incorrect. G6PD deficiency actually increases oxidative stress inside red blood cells because the reduced NADPH levels lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione. This makes the cells more susceptible to oxidative damage.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increased formation of Heinz body: Correct because this is a hallmark of G6PD deficiency due to oxidative damage to hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Males and females can be affected: Correct; while males are more commonly affected, females can also be affected due to the X-linked inheritance pattern.

 

Option C. Reduced NADPH: Correct because this is a direct consequence of G6PD deficiency as the enzyme is essential for NADPH production in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency increases oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and formation of Heinz bodies. It affects both males and females, though more commonly males.

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-4

 

IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

 

IL-4 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in promoting B-cell differentiation and class switching to produce IgE antibodies. It is primarily produced by T-helper 2 (Th2) cells and stimulates B-cells to undergo isotype switching, leading to the production of IgE instead of other antibody isotypes, such as IgG or IgM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2:

 

Role: IL-2 is crucial for T-cell proliferation, survival, and activation. It is not directly involved in the induction of IgE production by B-cells.

 

Option C. IL-1:

 

Role: IL-1 is involved in inflammation and immune responses, acting as a pro-inflammatory cytokine. It does not directly induce IgE production.

 

Option D. IL-6:

 

Role: IL-6 is important for inflammation, immune responses, and hematopoiesis. It has roles in the differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells, but it does not specifically induce IgE production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-4 is the key cytokine that stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE-secreting plasma cells, playing a crucial role in the allergic response and defense against parasites.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders has a high chance of catalase positive organisms causing infections?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex. This defect impairs the ability of phagocytes to produce reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for killing certain bacteria and fungi. As a result, individuals with CGD are particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms, which can neutralize hydrogen peroxide and thus evade destruction by the impaired phagocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgE syndrome: Also known as Job syndrome, this disorder is characterized by high levels of IgE, recurrent skin abscesses, pneumonia, and characteristic facial features. It is not specifically associated with increased infections by catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Bruton disease: Also known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, this condition affects B cell development, leading to low levels of immunoglobulins and increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, but not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency. While patients have an increased risk of infections, the susceptibility to catalase-positive organisms is not as pronounced as in CGD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic granulomatous disease is associated with a high risk of infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex, which impairs the killing of these organisms by phagocytes.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with long hands and feet, and a protruding lower jaw. Which of the following genes is most likely implicated in this scenario? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PIT1

 

Mutations of the pituitary-specific gene PIT-1 can lead to the development of a somatotroph adenoma which produces elevated levels of GH Growth hormone (and IGF-1) which can lead to acromegaly as given in the clinical scenario above.

 

Somatotrophs, mammosomatotrophs, and lactotrophs are derived from stem cells that express the pituitary transcription factor, PIT-1.

 

If the increased levels of GH are present after closure of the epiphyses, acromegaly develops. In this condition, growth is most conspicuously seen in

 

  • Skin and soft tissues, viscera (thyroid, heart, liver, and adrenals).
  • The bones of the face, hands, and feet are thickened and enlarged.
  • Bone density may increase (hyperostosis) in both the spine and the hips.
  • Enlargement and protrusion of the jaw is seen (prognathism), and broadening of the lower face.
  • The feet and hands are enlarged, and the fingers become thickened and sausage-like.

 

 

GH excess can also be associated with a variety of other manifestations, like gonadal dysfunction, diabetes mellitus, generalized muscle weakness, hypertension, arthritis, congestive heart failure, and an increased risk of gastrointestinal cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GATA1: This gene is associated with hematopoiesis and mutations in GATA1 are linked to blood disorders, not acromegaly.

 

Option C. TPIT (TBX19): This gene is involved in the development of corticotroph cells in the pituitary and is associated with ACTH production, not GH.

 

Option D. SF1 (Steroidogenic factor 1): SF1 is important in the development of the adrenal glands and gonads, and its mutations are associated with disorders of sex development, not acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PIT1 mutations are implicated in the development of somatotroph adenomas, leading to acromegaly with features such as enlarged hands, feet, and a protruding lower jaw.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathological basis of disease 8th edition pg 2129

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopic image of the lung tissue. A patient infected with SARS-COV2 presents with ARDS. The infection would affect and expand which of the labelled layers? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A  

 

The image given in the question demonstrates the electron microscopic image of the blood-air barrier in the lungs. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has been set in this patient with COVID-19. Damage to the endothelial (Labelled as A, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. Neutrophils play a significant role in tissue injury in this condition.

 

 

 

The electron micrograph shows at high magnification three components of the air-blood barrier in the alveolar septum. Gaseous exchange occurs across, 1) the cytoplasm of a type I alveolar cell or pneumocyte, P1; 2) the fused basal laminas (basement membranes) of type I alveolar and endothelial cells, BM; and 3) the cytoplasm of an endothelial cell, E, enclosing a blood capillary. Note the erythrocyte, Er, present within the lumen of the blood capillary. A fourth component of the air-blood barrier, surfactant, is not preserved in routine histological sections.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basement Membrane: While the basement membrane is part of the blood-air barrier, it is not the primary site of injury in ARDS.

 

Option C. Type I Alveolar cell/Pneumocyte: Although these cells are affected in ARDS, the endothelial cells are typically the first to be damaged.

 

Option D. Erythrocyte: The erythrocyte is not structurally affected by ARDS but rather suffers the consequences of impaired gas exchange due to endothelial and alveolar damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, especially in cases associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection, the primary injury occurs in the endothelial cells of the blood-air barrier, leading to inflammation, increased permeability, and subsequent respiratory failure.

choices.text: Factor VII
Factor V
Factor XII

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor XII

 

Factor XII, also known as Hageman factor, is part of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. Although Factor XII is essential in the laboratory-based tests for clotting, such as the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), its deficiency does not result in a bleeding tendency in vivo.

 

  • In vivo, tissue factor (TF) plays the central role in initiating the coagulation process, which primarily involves the extrinsic pathway. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by exposure of TF to the blood, which leads to the activation of Factor VII, and subsequently, the common pathway, ultimately forming a clot.
  • Factor XII deficiency does not cause bleeding in vivo because it is not required for the tissue factor pathway, which is the primary pathway for initiating coagulation in the body. In fact, people with Factor XII deficiency do not typically experience abnormal bleeding, despite having prolonged aPTT in laboratory tests.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor VII: Essential for the extrinsic pathway; deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

 

Option B. Factor V: Part of the common pathway; deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

 

Option D. Factor IX: Essential for the intrinsic pathway; deficiency causes Hemophilia B, a bleeding disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo. In vivo, tissue factor is the major initiator of coagulation. It is amplified by feedback loops involving thrombin.

choices.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries
Can be diagnosed with CECT
Improves with food rich in carbohydrates
Increased risk of GI lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is true about celiac disease? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased risk of GI lymphoma

 

Individuals with celiac disease have an increased risk of Gl lymphoma.

 

Celiac disease is also known as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is an immune mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing cereals, such as barley, rye, oats & wheat (BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. In countries where most people are Caucasians of European ancestry, celiac disease is a common disorder, with an estimated prevalence of 0.5% to 1%.

 

The histopathology is characterized by increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy. This loss of mucosal and brush-border surface area accounts for the malabsorption.

 

 

Noninvasive serologic tests are generally performed prior to biopsy. The most sensitive tests are the presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin. Anti-endomysial antibodies are highly specific but less sensitive than other antibodies.

 

Individuals with celiac disease have a higher-than-normal rate of malignancy. The most common celiac disease–associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

 

The treatment is lifelong gluten free diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries: This is incorrect. While celiac disease can cause malnutrition due to malabsorption, it is not the most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries. Infectious diseases, poor diet, and other factors are more common causes.

 

Option B. Can be diagnosed with CECT: This is incorrect. Celiac disease is not typically diagnosed with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT). The diagnosis is usually based on serologic tests for specific antibodies and confirmed by duodenal biopsy showing characteristic histopathological changes such as villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis.

 

Option C. Improves with food rich in carbohydrates: This is incorrect. Celiac disease improves with a gluten-free diet, not with an increase in carbohydrates. The treatment requires strict lifelong avoidance of gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of gastrointestinal lymphoma, specifically enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, making it a critical long-term concern for individuals with this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1518-1519

choices.text: LAP score
FISH and PCR

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 50,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myoblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

 

The clinical picture of fatigue, splenomegaly, and peripheral blood smear findings suggest chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are used to detect the BCR-ABL gene, which is specific for CML.

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder that most commonly affects people in their fifth to sixth decade of life. A reciprocal (9;22) (g34;g11) translocation results in the creation of the chimeric BC-ABL gene (Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene differentiates ML from other myeloproliferative disorders and can be detected using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) .

 

Clinical characteristics:

 

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.

 

Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

 

Peripheral blood:

 

  • Severe leukocytosis with a leukocyte count that frequently exceeds 100,000 cells/mm, primarily composed of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Moderate normocytic normochromic anemia - Rising basophilia indicates impending blastic transformation.
  • The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • Blastic phase or blast crisis in CML satisfies the definition of acute leukemia by having more than 20% blood or marrow blasts.
  • Anemia of moderate severity - A rising basophilia is indicative of impending blastic transformation. - The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • A blast phase or blast crisis in CML meets the definition of acute leukemia by having blood or marrow blasts of more than 20%.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunophenotyping: Used for the diagnosis of various hematologic malignancies, particularly lymphoid neoplasms. It is less specific for CML.

 

Option  B. LAP score (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase): The LAP score is typically low in CML, but this test is less specific and has largely been replaced by molecular diagnostic techniques like FISH and PCR.

 

Option D. Flow cytometry: Useful for identifying and classifying hematologic malignancies based on cell surface markers but is not the most specific test for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are the most sensitive investigations for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the hallmark of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). These tests are crucial for accurate diagnosis and monitoring of CML.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestos

 

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura.

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the subpleural areas and in the bases of lungs. The advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

 

Gross appearance of the lung in asbestosis diagram

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • There is non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • There is presence of characteristic asbestos bodies in the involved areas. These are asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell-shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silica: Silica exposure leads to silicosis, which is characterized by nodular fibrosis, not asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Coal dust: Coal dust exposure leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) or "black lung disease," characterized by coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

 

Option D. Cotton: Cotton dust exposure leads to byssinosis, which is primarily associated with respiratory symptoms but does not cause the fibrosis and asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies and interstitial fibrosis, typically seen in individuals working in industries involving asbestos exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

 

Silicosis (1-d): Silicosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of silica dust, often found in industries like mining, sandblasting, and stone cutting. The term "crazy pavement" refers to a radiologic pattern seen in acute silicosis, which involves interstitial thickening and nodular fibrosis.

 

Mesothelioma (2-b): Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura, most commonly associated with asbestos exposure. It typically presents with a pleural effusion that does not cause a mediastinal shift, distinguishing it from other causes of pleural effusion.

 

Caplan syndrome (3-c): Caplan syndrome is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis (particularly coal workers' pneumoconiosis, also known as anthracosis). It was first identified in coal workers.

 

Asbestosis (4-a): Asbestosis is a lung disease resulting from the inhalation of asbestos fibers. It primarily affects the lower (basal) lobes of the lungs and can lead to fibrosis and increased risk of lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely tumor arising from the slide shown in the image?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma

 

The provided histopathological image shows multiple gland formations, which is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinomas are malignant tumors that arise from glandular epithelial cells. The presence of glandular structures in the histological slide is a key indicator of this type of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of carcinoma is characterized by the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, which are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of the lymphoid tissue and do not typically show glandular patterns in histology.

 

Option D. Sarcoma: Sarcomas arise from mesenchymal cells and are characterized by spindle-shaped cells. They do not exhibit glandular formations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is identified by the presence of glandular formations in histopathological slides.

questions.text: Which of the following proto-oncogenes is not implicated in carcinoma of thyroid? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) p53

 

p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene like other 3 options.

 

Proto-oncogenes are genes that, when mutated or overexpressed, have the potential to cause normal cells to become cancerous by promoting cell growth and division. On the other hand, tumor suppressor genes like p53 work to prevent uncontrolled cell growth. The p53 gene, often referred to as the "guardian of the genome," plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle, DNA repair, and apoptosis (programmed cell death). When p53 is mutated, it can no longer effectively suppress tumor growth, leading to the development of cancer. However, p53 is not categorized as a proto-oncogene and is not directly implicated in thyroid carcinoma as an oncogenic driver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 520

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability and pallor presented to the OPD. The image of her hand is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Knuckle pigmentation is an easily visible and early sign of vitamin B12 deficiency due to increase in tyrosinase activity. It may occur even before the development of hematological and neurological complications.

 

In megaloblastic anemia, there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: This condition involves pancytopenia and hypocellular bone marrow but does not typically present with knuckle pigmentation.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia usually presents with pallor and fatigue but is not associated with knuckle pigmentation.

 

Option D. Hypoalbuminemia: Hypoalbuminemia may cause edema and other systemic symptoms but is not associated with knuckle pigmentation or anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Knuckle pigmentation is an early and visible sign of vitamin B12 deficiency, which can precede the more severe hematological and neurological complications associated with megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass, which on histopathological examination had the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. The classical presentation includes leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and an intraocular mass. Histopathologically, the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a key diagnostic feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes characterized by a circular arrangement of tumor cells around an empty lumen, resembling a flower.

 

In this case:

 

  • Leukocoria is a typical clinical presentation of retinoblastoma.
  • The intraocular mass in a child further supports this diagnosis.
  • The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes confirms the diagnosis, as they are pathognomonic for retinoblastoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: While melanoma can occur in the eye, it is more common in adults and typically does not present with leukocoria or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Intraocular lymphoma is rare in children and typically presents differently, without the characteristic rosettes seen in retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This malignancy affects the ocular surface and is not typically associated with intraocular masses or leukocoria. It also lacks the histological pattern of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is identified by leukocoria, an intraocular mass in children, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology, which are true rosettes specific to this diagnosis.

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis
Mutation in dynein arms
Antibodies against type-IV collagen

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency 

 

The gross specimen shown above has emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus, indicating panacinar emphysema. It is caused by a lack of alpha-1-antitrypsin.

 

The acini in this type are uniformly enlarged from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. The prefix "pan" denotes the entire acinus but not the entire lung. Panacinar emphysema, as opposed to centriacinar emphysema, is more common in the lower zones and anterior margins of the lung, and it is usually most severe at the bases. This type of emphysema is linked to a lack of alpha 1-antitrypsin (AT).

 

 

 

A, Centriacinar emphysema. Central areas show marked emphysematous damage (E), surrounded by relatively spared alveolar spaces. B, Panacinar emphysema involving the entire pulmonary lobule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis:

 

  • Pathology: Cystic fibrosis is characterized by thick, sticky mucus production leading to recurrent lung infections and bronchiectasis, not emphysema.
  • Etiology: Caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to defective chloride channels.

 

Option C. Mutation in dynein arms:

 

Pathology: Dynein arm mutations are associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), which leads to impaired mucociliary clearance and recurrent respiratory infections, but not typically emphysema.

 

Option D. Antibodies against type-IV collagen:

 

Pathology: Associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which causes pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis, not emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder leading to a lack of AAT, which protects the lung tissue from elastase. The deficiency causes panacinar emphysema, characterized by uniform enlargement of acini, particularly in the lower lobes of the lung, and presents with chronic respiratory symptoms.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are false about IL-12 except? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases production of interferon- γ
  2. Inhibits T cells
  3. Inhibits B cells
  4. Produced by macrophages
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is a cytokine produced primarily by antigen-presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells. It plays a critical role in the immune response by promoting the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells, which are essential for cell-mediated immunity.

 

1. Increases production of interferon-γ (IFN-γ): IL-12 stimulates T cells and natural killer (NK) cells to produce IFN-γ, a cytokine crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

4. Produced by macrophages: IL-12 is indeed produced by macrophages, along with other antigen-presenting cells, in response to pathogens.

 

Other options:

 

2. Inhibits T cells: This is incorrect. IL-12 actually activates T cells, particularly promoting the differentiation into Th1 cells, rather than inhibiting them.

 

3. Inhibits B cells: This is also incorrect. IL-12 does not inhibit B cells; instead, it indirectly influences B cell function by promoting a Th1 response, which supports cellular immunity over humoral (B cell) immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon- γ (IFN- γ).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to OPD with swelling in the upper part of the tibia. X-ray revealed periosteal reaction in upper diaphysis of tibia. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario, immunohistochemistry showing positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 with histopath image showing small round blue cells, points to a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is an osteoid forming tumor. Patient usually complains of Night pain. But it neither shows small round blue cells on biopsy nor is positive for MIC-2

 

Option C. Metastatic neuroblastoma: Metastatic neuroblastoma also shows Homer wright pseudo rosettes, but it is positive for NSE, PHOX 28.

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma (Giant cell tumor): Osteoclastoma is a benign, locally aggressive bone tumor that is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells on biopsy. It typically affects the epiphysis of long bones and does not present with small round blue cells or positive staining for MIC-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing sarcoma is a small round blue cell tumor commonly occurring in the diaphysis of long bones in adolescents. It is characterized by positive immunohistochemical staining for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 (CD99).

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2390-2391

choices.text: Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1 mutation

questions.text: All leukemias come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumours except: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B-lymphoblastic leukemia/ lymphoma with hypodiploidy

 

It is not a provisional entity under WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

 

Leukemias that come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid are:

 

  1. Myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with PCM1-JAK2
  2. Refractory cytopenia of childhood
  3. AML with BCR-ABL1
  4. AML with mutated RUNX1 (Option C)
  5. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, BCR-ABL1–like
  6. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with iAMP21
  7. Early T-cell precursor lymphoblastic leukemia
  8. Natural killer (NK) cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (Option A)
  9. Splenic B-cell lymphoma/leukemia, unclassifiable (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO 2016 classification introduced several provisional entities in hematolymphoid neoplasms, which are conditions that are newly recognized or still under study for their clinical significance.

 

B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with hypodiploidy is not a provisional entity under the WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

Autoimmunity refers to immune reactions against self-antigens. Normal persons are unresponsive (tolerant) to their own (self) antigens, and autoimmunity results from a failure of self-tolerance.

 

Self-tolerance involves two broad mechanisms: Central Tolerance and Peripheral Tolerance.

 

AIRE (Autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some peripheral tissue-restricted self-antigens in the thymus and is critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these self-antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: NOTCH1 plays a role in cell growth and division (proliferation), maturation (differentiation), and self-destruction (apoptosis).

 

Option B. E2A: E2A proteins function by recruiting proteins that drive epigenetic remodeling that precedes transcription.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Recombination-activating genes RAG 1 and RAG 2 initiate the molecular processes that lead to lymphocyte receptor formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

 

Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect.

 

Berry (Saccular) aneurysms occur when there is collagen deficiency in the internal elastic lamina and breakdown of the tunica media. An outpouching, consisting of only tunica intima and adventitia, protrudes through the defect in the internal elastic lamina and tunica media to produce the aneurismal sac

 

As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually ≤0.5 mm long.

 

The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm.

 

Saccular/ Berry aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm. About 90% of saccular aneurysms are found near major arterial branch points in the anterior circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN: While hypertension (HTN) is a risk factor that can exacerbate the progression of an aneurysm, it is not the primary cause of Berry aneurysm formation. The initial defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Option C. Endothelial layer defect: The endothelial layer is the innermost lining of blood vessels, but defects in this layer alone do not cause Berry aneurysms. The structural weakness in Berry aneurysms is primarily related to the internal elastic lamina and the underlying media.

 

Option D. Adventitia defect: The adventitia is the outermost layer of the blood vessel, but defects in the adventitia alone are not responsible for the formation of Berry aneurysms. The crucial defect is in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Berry aneurysms occur due to a defect in the arterial internal elastic lamina, leading to a weakened vessel wall and the potential for aneurysmal outpouching and rupture.

choices.text: CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

questions.text: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

 

The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl's eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia.

 

CMV is a -group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

 

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Small-cell lung cancer: This does not present with the characteristic owl's eye appearance seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. Cryptococcal pneumonia: Cryptococcosis is a fungal infection that can affect the lungs but typically presents with encapsulated yeast forms, not the cytomegalic cells characteristic of CMV.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: TB typically presents with granulomas and caseating necrosis rather than the cytomegalic changes seen in CMV pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of owl's eye intranuclear inclusions in pneumocytes on lung biopsy, especially in an immunocompromised patient, is strongly suggestive of CMV-associated organizing pneumonia.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 639-640
